input: What are the best free icon libraries for 2024 and 2025 like Font Awesome and Material Icons that have a CDN?
output:
Here are the best free icon libraries with CDN support for 2024-2025:

## Top Options

**Font Awesome**
- 2,016+ free icons (more in paid version)
- Available as SVG, webfonts, and multiple formats
- Easy framework integration (React, Vue, Angular)
- CDN: `<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/font-awesome/6.x.x/css/all.min.css">`

**Material Icons/Material Symbols (Google)**
- 2,500+ customizable icons
- Part of Material Design system
- Outline and solid styles available
- CDN: `<link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">`

**Lineicons**
- 30,000+ total icons (2,000+ free)
- 60+ categories
- Free CDN included
- Modern frameworks support (React, Vue, Next.js, Svelte)

**Hugeicons**
- 3,800+ free icons
- Multiple formats (React, SVG, CDN, NPM)
- React Native and Figma plugin support

**Boxicons**
- 3,000+ free icons
- SVG, PNG, and webfont formats
- Highly customizable

**Feather Icons**
- Minimalist line-based icons
- Clean, simple design
- Lightweight SVG files

**Heroicons**
- 316+ icons by Tailwind CSS team
- Outline and solid styles
- Perfect for modern web apps

All of these provide CDN links for quick integration without downloading files. Font Awesome and Material Icons remain the most widely used, while Lineicons offers the largest free collection.

Sources:
- [10+ Best Open Source Icon Libraries in 2024 - DEV Community](https://dev.to/masumparvej/10-best-open-source-icon-libraries-3pf6)
- [21+ Best Free and Open-Source Icon Library for 2025 - DEV Community](https://dev.to/icons/21-best-open-source-icon-libraries-o5n)
- [15+ Best Icon Libraries for 2025 - DEV Community](https://dev.to/vinishbhaskar/best-icon-libraries-28ce)
- [Best Open Source Icon Libraries in 2025 - Mockflow](https://mockflow.com/blog/best-open-source-icon-libraries)
- [25+ Best Open Source Icon Libraries in 2026 | Lineicons](https://lineicons.com/blog/best-open-source-icon-libraries)
- [15 Free Icon Libraries To Use In 2025](https://hugeicons.com/blog/design/15-free-icon-library-to-use-in-2024)

input: where is the github source code for pandabox on astro-lightbox.netlify.app from 2026?
output:
The GitHub source code for PandaBox on astro-lightbox.netlify.app is located at:

**https://github.com/SaintSin/astro-pandabox**

This is a lightweight Lightbox and gallery component for Astro, created by SaintSin. The demo site at astro-lightbox.netlify.app showcases the component's features, which include:

- Fade and slide-in transition types
- Gallery support using JSON files
- Content Collections API integration
- Requires Astro 5+

Sources:
- [GitHub - SaintSin/astro-pandabox: A lightweight Lightbox and gallery component for Astro](https://github.com/SaintSin/astro-pandabox)
- [PandaBox: An Astro Lightbox and Gallery](https://astro-lightbox.netlify.app/)
- [What's new in Astro - November 2024 | Astro](https://astro.build/blog/whats-new-november-2024/)
- [Customizable Lightbox & Gallery Component for Astro - Pandabox](https://next.jqueryscript.net/astro/lightbox-gallery-pandabox/)

input: How to use vite-plugin-vue-cron with Vue 3 and Element Plus in 2026
output:
Based on my search, I found that the correct package is **`@vue-js-cron/element-plus`** (not "vite-plugin-vue-cron"). Here's how to use it with Vue 3 and Element Plus:

## Installation

```bash
npm i @vue-js-cron/element-plus
```

## Basic Setup

The package provides a renderless cron editor component that integrates seamlessly with Element Plus UI components. Here's how to use it:

```javascript
// In your Vue 3 component
import { CronElement } from '@vue-js-cron/element-plus'

export default {
  components: {
    CronElement
  },
  data() {
    return {
      cronExpression: '0 0 * * *'
    }
  }
}
```

```vue
<template>
  <CronElement v-model="cronExpression" />
</template>
```

## Key Features

- **Renderless Core**: Built on a renderless Vue.js component that generates cron expressions
- **Element Plus Integration**: Uses native Element Plus components for the UI
- **Latest Version**: v3.1.10 (published recently in 2026)
- **Vite Compatible**: Works seamlessly with Vite build tool
- **TypeScript Support**: Fully typed for TypeScript projects

## Additional Information

The `@vue-js-cron` project supports multiple UI frameworks:
- `@vue-js-cron/element-plus` (Element Plus)
- `@vue-js-cron/vuetify` (Vuetify)
- `@vue-js-cron/ant` (Ant Design Vue)
- `@vue-js-cron/prime` (PrimeVue)
- `@vue-js-cron/light` (No external dependencies)

For detailed documentation, configuration options, and examples, visit the official documentation site.

Sources:
- [@vue-js-cron/element-plus - npm](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@vue-js-cron/element-plus)
- [GitHub - abichinger/vue-js-cron: Renderless Vue.js cron editor](https://github.com/abichinger/vue-js-cron)
- [Getting Started - Light | Vue-js-cron Docs](https://abichinger.github.io/vue-js-cron/guide/getting-started-light)
- [Releases · abichinger/vue-js-cron](https://github.com/abichinger/vue-js-cron/releases)

input: How do I handle memory state management and RAG context injection in LangGraph for 2026?
output:
Based on the latest 2026 information, here's a comprehensive guide to memory state management and RAG context injection in LangGraph:

## Memory State Management in LangGraph (2026)

### Two-Tier Memory Architecture

**1. Short-Term Memory (Thread-Scoped)**
- Managed through checkpointers that persist state at every "super-step"
- Contains conversation history, uploaded files, retrieved documents, and working context
- Uses "threads" to represent individual sessions/conversations
- Enables human-in-the-loop workflows and fault tolerance

**2. Long-Term Memory (Cross-Thread)**
- Stores information across conversations for learning and personalization
- Integrations available: MongoDB Store, Redis, PostgreSQL
- Supports both Python and JavaScript implementations

### State Management Best Practices

**TypedDict with Reducers:**
```python
from typing import TypedDict, Annotated
from operator import add

class State(TypedDict):
    messages: Annotated[list, add]  # Reducer prevents overwriting
    retrieved_docs: list
    user_preferences: dict
```

**Production Checkpointers:**
- **Development**: `MemorySaver` (in-memory only)
- **Testing**: `SqliteSaver` (disk persistence)
- **Production**: `PostgresSaver` or `CosmosDBSaver` (scalable, multi-tenant)

Install for production:
```bash
pip install langgraph-checkpoint-postgres
```

## RAG Context Injection Patterns (2026)

The paradigm has shifted from linear RAG to **Agentic RAG** with iterative refinement:

### Core Patterns

**1. Adaptive Routing**
- Routes queries dynamically based on complexity
- Simple queries → LLM parametric knowledge
- Complex queries → vector search
- Time-sensitive → web search

**2. Corrective RAG**
- Evaluates retrieved documents for relevance
- Rewrites queries if documents score poorly
- Falls back to alternative retrieval methods

**3. Self-Reflective RAG**
- Generates answer, then validates for hallucinations
- Regenerates with additional constraints if validation fails
- Uses critic loops for iterative refinement

**4. Evidence-Gap Analysis**
- LLM orchestrates retrieval decisions
- Identifies missing information
- Decomposes complex queries into sub-queries
- Synthesizes answers from multiple retrieval passes

### Implementation Architecture

```python
from langgraph.graph import StateGraph, MessagesState

# State includes accumulated context
class RAGState(MessagesState):
    retrieved_docs: list
    relevance_scores: list
    query_rewrites: int

# Multi-step retrieval with evaluation
graph = StateGraph(RAGState)
graph.add_node("retrieve", retrieve_docs)
graph.add_node("evaluate", grade_relevance)
graph.add_node("generate", generate_answer)
graph.add_node("validate", check_hallucinations)
```

### 2026 Production Features

- **Hybrid search**: Dense + BM25 vectors combined
- **Rerankers**: Cohere/BGE for improved relevance
- **Cited answers**: Provenance tracking with audit trails
- **JSONL traces**: Full observability for evaluation

### Key Insight

The fundamental shift is from **one-shot context injection** to **adaptive, iterative context injection** where the system continuously refines what context to inject based on evaluation of retrieved documents and generated answers.

## Sources

- [Memory overview - LangChain Docs](https://docs.langchain.com/oss/python/langgraph/memory)
- [LangGraph Explained (2026 Edition)](https://medium.com/@dewasheesh.rana/langgraph-explained-2026-edition-ea8f725abff3)
- [Launching Long-Term Memory Support in LangGraph](https://www.blog.langchain.com/launching-long-term-memory-support-in-langgraph/)
- [Mastering LangGraph State Management in 2025](https://sparkco.ai/blog/mastering-langgraph-state-management-in-2025)
- [Powering Long-Term Memory for Agents With LangGraph and MongoDB](https://www.mongodb.com/company/blog/product-release-announcements/powering-long-term-memory-for-agents-langgraph)
- [Building Agentic RAG Systems with LangGraph: The 2026 Guide](https://rahulkolekar.com/building-agentic-rag-systems-with-langgraph/)
- [RAG Frameworks in 2026: LangChain, LangGraph vs LlamaIndex](https://research.aimultiple.com/rag-frameworks/)
- [GOODBYE BASIC RAG — HELLO AGENTS: THE 2026 PLAYBOOK](https://medium.com/@krtarunsingh/goodbye-basic-rag-hello-agents-the-2026-playbook-python-langgraph-llamaindex-27e9f70f3428)
- [Persistence - LangChain Docs](https://docs.langchain.com/oss/python/langgraph/persistence)
- [Mastering LangGraph Checkpointing: Best Practices for 2025](https://sparkco.ai/blog/mastering-langgraph-checkpointing-best-practices-for-2025)
